pandas.description: The pandas library provides high-level data structures and data analysis tools for Python, primarily through its two main classes: Series (1-dimensional) and DataFrame (2-dimensional). It offers a variety of functions for data manipulation and analysis, handling missing data, and merging and joining datasets.

read_csv.description: Reads a comma-separated values (CSV) file into a DataFrame.

parameters.name: filepath_or_buffer
parameters.description: Path to the file or object to read from.

parameters.name: sep
parameters.description: Delimiter to use. For example, use '\t' for tab-separated values.

parameters.name: header
parameters.description: Row number(s) to use as the column names. Defaults to the first line of the file.

parameters.name: names
parameters.description: List of column names to use. If file contains no header row, then you should explicitly pass header=None.

parameters.name: index_col
parameters.type: int, str, sequence of int / str, or False, default None
parameters.description: Column(s) to set as index(MultiIndex).

parameters.name: dtype
parameters.type: Type name or dict of column -> type, optional
parameters.description: Data type for data or columns. E.g. {'a': np.float64, 'b': np.int32}

parameters.name: parse_dates
parameters.type: bool or list of int or names or list of lists or dict, default False
parameters.description: Parse dates. E.g. if True -> try parsing the index, if [1, 2, 3] -> try parsing columns 1, 2, 3.

parameters.name: na_values
parameters.type: scalar, str, list-like, or dict, default None
parameters.description: Additional strings to recognize as NA/NaN.

parameters.name: thousands
parameters.description: Thousands separator.

read_csv.example:
import pandas as pd

df = pd.read_csv('/path/to/file.csv', sep=',', header=0, index_col=None)

DataFrame.description: Two-dimensional, size-mutable, potentially heterogeneous tabular data.

parameters.name: data
parameters.description: Data to populate the DataFrame with.

parameters.name: index
parameters.description: Index to use for the resulting DataFrame.

parameters.name: columns
parameters.description: Column labels to use for the resulting DataFrame.

parameters.name: dtype
parameters.description: Data type to force. Only a single dtype is allowed.

parameters.name: copy
parameters.description: Copy data from inputs. Only affects DataFrame / 2d ndarray input.

DataFrame.example:
import pandas as pd

df = pd.DataFrame(data={'col1': [1, 2], 'col2': [3, 4]})

merge.description: Merge DataFrame or named Series objects with a database-style join.

parameters.name: left
parameters.description: Left DataFrame or Series to merge.

parameters.name: right
parameters.description: Right DataFrame or Series to merge.

parameters.name: how
parameters.description: Type of merge to be performed. Options are 'left', 'right', 'outer', 'inner'.

parameters.name: on
parameters.description: Column or index level names to join on. Must be found in both DataFrames.

parameters.name: left_on
parameters.description: Column or index level names to join on in the left DataFrame.

parameters.name: right_on
parameters.description: Column or index level names to join on in the right DataFrame.

merge.example:
import pandas as pd

df1 = pd.DataFrame({'key': ['K0', 'K1', 'K2'], 'A': ['A0', 'A1', 'A2']})
df2 = pd.DataFrame({'key': ['K0', 'K1', 'K3'], 'B': ['B0', 'B1', 'B3']})
result = pd.merge(df1, df2, on='key', how='inner')

drop.description: Remove rows or columns by specifying label names and corresponding axis, or by specifying directly index or column names.

parameters.name: labels
parameters.description: Index or column labels to drop.

parameters.name: axis
parameters.description: Whether to drop labels from the index (0 or 'index') or columns (1 or 'columns').

parameters.name: inplace
parameters.description: If True, do operation inplace and return None.

parameters.name: errors
parameters.description: If 'ignore', suppress error and only existing labels are dropped.

drop.example:
import pandas as pd

df = pd.DataFrame({'A': [1, 2, 3], 'B': [4, 5, 6], 'C': [7, 8, 9]})
df = df.drop(['B'], axis=1)

groupby.description: Group DataFrame using a mapper or by a Series of columns, and apply a function to the groups.

parameters.name: by
parameters.type: mapping, function, label, or list of labels
parameters.description: Used to determine the groups for the groupby.

parameters.name: axis
parameters.description: Split along rows (0) or columns (1).

parameters.name: level
parameters.type: int, level name, or sequence of such, default None
parameters.description: If the axis is a MultiIndex (hierarchical), group by a particular level or levels.

parameters.name: as_index
parameters.description: For aggregated output, return object with group labels as the index.

groupby.example:
import pandas as pd

df = pd.DataFrame({'A': ['foo', 'bar', 'foo', 'bar'], 'B': [1, 2, 3, 4]})
grouped = df.groupby('A').sum()

pivot_table.description: Create a spreadsheet-style pivot table as a DataFrame.

parameters.name: data
parameters.description: DataFrame to pivot.

parameters.name: values
parameters.type: column to aggregate or list of columns
parameters.description: Column(s) to aggregate.

parameters.name: index
parameters.type: column, list of columns, or keys
parameters.description: Column(s) to set as index.

parameters.name: columns
parameters.type: column, list of columns, or keys
parameters.description: Column(s) to set as columns.

parameters.name: aggfunc
parameters.type: function, list of functions, dict, or default 'mean'
parameters.description: Function to use for aggregation.

pivot_table.example:
import pandas as pd

df = pd.DataFrame({'A': ['foo', 'foo', 'bar', 'bar'], 'B': ['one', 'two', 'one', 'two'], 'C': [1, 3, 2, 4]})
pivot = df.pivot_table(values='C', index='A', columns='B', aggfunc='sum')

concat.description: Concatenate pandas objects along a particular axis with optional set logic along the other axes.

parameters.name: objs
parameters.type: a sequence or mapping of Series or DataFrame objects
parameters.description: The Series or DataFrame objects to be concatenated.

parameters.name: axis
parameters.description: The axis to concatenate along. 0 for rows, 1 for columns.

parameters.name: join
parameters.description: How to handle indexes on other axes. 'outer' for union, 'inner' for intersection.

parameters.name: ignore_index
parameters.description: If True, do not use the index values along the concatenation axis. The resulting axis will be labeled 0, â€¦, n-1.

parameters.name: keys
parameters.description: If provided, use the provided key values to construct a hierarchical index.

concat.example:
import pandas as pd

df1 = pd.DataFrame({'A': ['A0', 'A1', 'A2'], 'B': ['B0', 'B1', 'B2']})
df2 = pd.DataFrame({'A': ['A3', 'A4', 'A5'], 'B': ['B3', 'B4', 'B5']})
result = pd.concat([df1, df2], axis=0, ignore_index=True)

fillna.description: Fill NA/NaN values using the specified method.

parameters.name: value
parameters.description: Value to use to fill holes (e.g., 0).

parameters.name: method
parameters.description: Method to use for filling holes ('backfill', 'bfill', 'pad', 'ffill').

parameters.name: axis
parameters.description: Axis along which to fill missing values.

parameters.name: inplace
parameters.description: If True, fill in place and return None.

fillna.example:
import pandas as pd

df = pd.DataFrame({'A': [1, None, 3], 'B': [None, 2, 3]})
df_filled = df.fillna(0)

apply.description: Apply a function along an axis of the DataFrame.

parameters.name: func
parameters.description: Function to apply to each column or row.

parameters.name: axis
parameters.description: Axis along which the function is applied. 0 or 'index' means apply function to each column; 1 or 'columns' means apply function to each row.

parameters.name: raw
parameters.description: If False, the function is passed a Series object for each column or row.

parameters.name: result_type
parameters.description: The kind of result to return when applying the function. Options are 'expand', 'reduce', 'broadcast', or None.

apply.example:
import pandas as pd

df = pd.DataFrame({'A': [1, 2, 3], 'B': [4, 5, 6]})
def add_one(x): return x + 1
df_applied = df.apply(add_one)

sort_values.description: Sort by the values along either axis.

parameters.name: by
parameters.description: Column(s) to sort by.

parameters.name: axis
parameters.description: Axis to sort along. 0 for index, 1 for columns.

parameters.name: ascending
parameters.type: bool or list of bool, default True
parameters.description: Sort ascending vs. descending. If list of bool, must match the length of the by.

parameters.name: inplace
parameters.description: If True, perform operation in place.

parameters.name: na_position
parameters.description: Puts NaNs at the beginning if 'first'; 'last' puts NaNs at the end.

sort_values.example:
import pandas as pd

df = pd.DataFrame({'A': [2, 1, 3], 'B': [1, 2, 3]})
df_sorted = df.sort_values(by='A')

iloc.description: Purely integer-location based indexing for selection by position.

parameters.name: i
parameters.type: int, slice, or list of int
parameters.description: Row position(s) to select.

parameters.name: j
parameters.type: int, slice, or list of int
parameters.description: Column position(s) to select.

iloc.example:
import pandas as pd

df = pd.DataFrame({'A': [1, 2, 3], 'B': [4, 5, 6]})
value = df.iloc[0, 1]

to_csv.description: Write DataFrame to a comma-separated values (CSV) file.

parameters.name: path_or_buf
parameters.type: str or file-like object, default None
parameters.description: File path or object. If None is provided, the result is returned as a string.

parameters.name: sep
parameters.description: String of length 1. Field delimiter for the output file.

parameters.name: index
parameters.description: Write row names (index).

parameters.name: header
parameters.type: bool or list of str, default True
parameters.description: Write out the column names. If a list of string is given, it is assumed to be aliases for the column names.

parameters.name: columns
parameters.description: Columns to write.

to_csv.example:
import pandas as pd

df = pd.DataFrame({'A': [1, 2, 3], 'B': [4, 5, 6]})
df.to_csv('/path/to/file.csv')

read_excel.description: Reads an Excel file into a pandas DataFrame.

parameters.name: io
parameters.description: The path to the Excel file.

parameters.name: sheet_name
parameters.type: str, int, list, or None, default 0
parameters.description: Name or index of sheet or sheets to read. If None, all sheets are read.

parameters.name: header
parameters.description: Row number(s) to use as the column names.

parameters.name: names
parameters.description: List of column names to use.

parameters.name: index_col
parameters.type: int, str, sequence of int / str, or False, default None
parameters.description: Column(s) to set as index(MultiIndex).

parameters.name: usecols
parameters.type: int, str, list-like, or callable, optional
parameters.description: Return a subset of the columns.

read_excel.example:
import pandas as pd

df = pd.read_excel('/path/to/file.xlsx', sheet_name='Sheet1', header=0)

crosstab.description: Computes a simple cross-tabulation of two (or more) factors. By default computes a frequency table of the factors unless an array of values and an aggregation function are passed.

parameters.name: index
parameters.type: array-like, Series, or list of arrays/Series
parameters.description: Values to group by in the rows.

parameters.name: columns
parameters.type: array-like, Series, or list of arrays/Series
parameters.description: Values to group by in the columns.

parameters.name: values
parameters.description: Array of values to aggregate according to the factors.

parameters.name: aggfunc
parameters.description: If specified, applies aggregation function to the data.

parameters.name: margins
parameters.description: Add row/column margins (subtotals).

parameters.name: normalize
parameters.description: Normalize by dividing all values by the sum of values.

crosstab.example:
import pandas as pd

data = {'A': [1, 2, 1], 'B': [2, 2, 3]}
df = pd.DataFrame(data)
crosstab_result = pd.crosstab(df['A'], df['B'])

melt.description: Unpivots a DataFrame from wide format to long format, optionally leaving identifiers set.

parameters.name: frame
parameters.description: The DataFrame to unpivot.

parameters.name: id_vars
parameters.description: Column(s) to use as identifier variables.

parameters.name: value_vars
parameters.description: Column(s) to unpivot. If not specified, uses all columns that are not set as `id_vars`.

parameters.name: var_name
parameters.description: Name to use for the `variable` column.

parameters.name: value_name
parameters.description: Name to use for the `value` column.

melt.example:
import pandas as pd

df = pd.DataFrame({'A': ['a', 'b', 'c'], 'B': [1, 2, 3], 'C': [4, 5, 6]})
result = pd.melt(df, id_vars=['A'], value_vars=['B', 'C'], var_name='my_var', value_name='my_val')

dropna.description: Remove missing values from a DataFrame or Series.

parameters.name: axis
parameters.description: Determine if rows or columns which contain missing values are removed. 0 or 'index' for rows, 1 or 'columns' for columns.

parameters.name: how
parameters.description: 'any' will drop rows/columns that contain any missing values. 'all' will drop rows/columns where all elements are missing.

parameters.name: thresh
parameters.description: Require that many non-NA values to retain the row/column. If not specified, drop rows/columns with any or all missing values.

parameters.name: subset
parameters.description: Labels along other axis to consider. For example, if you are dropping rows, these would be a list of columns to include.

parameters.name: inplace
parameters.description: If True, do operation in place and return None.

dropna.example:
import pandas as pd

df = pd.DataFrame({'A': [1, None, 3], 'B': [4, 5, None]})
result = df.dropna()

values.description: Return a Numpy representation of the DataFrame or Series.
values.example:
import pandas as pd

df = pd.DataFrame({'A': [1, 2, 3], 'B': [4, 5, 6]})
array = df.values

std.description: Return sample standard deviation over requested axis.

parameters.name: axis
parameters.description: Axis for the function to be applied on. 0 or 'index' for rows, 1 or 'columns' for columns.

parameters.name: skipna
parameters.description: Exclude NA/null values when computing the result.

parameters.name: level
parameters.description: If the axis is a MultiIndex (hierarchical), count along a particular level, collapsing into a DataFrame.

parameters.name: ddof
parameters.description: Delta Degrees of Freedom. The divisor used in calculations is N - ddof, where N represents the number of elements.

parameters.name: numeric_only
parameters.description: Include only float, int, boolean columns. If None, will attempt to use everything, then use only numeric data.

std.example:
import pandas as pd

df = pd.DataFrame({'A': [1, 2, 3], 'B': [4, 5, 6]})
std_dev = df.std()

reset_index.description: Reset the index of the DataFrame, and use the default one. Optionally, remove the index, rather than moving it to the columns.

parameters.name: level
parameters.type: int, str, tuple, or list, default None
parameters.description: Only remove the given levels from the index. Removes all levels by default.

parameters.name: drop
parameters.description: Do not try to insert index into DataFrame columns. This resets the index to the default integer index.

parameters.name: inplace
parameters.description: Modify the DataFrame in place (do not create a new object).

parameters.name: col_level
parameters.description: If the columns have multiple levels, determines which level the labels are inserted into.

parameters.name: col_fill
parameters.description: If the columns have multiple levels, determines how the other levels are named.

reset_index.example:
import pandas as pd

df = pd.DataFrame({'A': [1, 2, 3], 'B': [4, 5, 6]})
df_reset = df.reset_index()
